Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
I glance at my phone, seeing a text from Alex: “Which night are we having our date? I’m free all week!” I smile, picturing his hopeful face, but my mind is already racing. At work, my headset feels heavier than usual. The new service we’re selling is complicated, and every call is a minefield of technical questions. The script barely scratches the surface, and customers grow impatient when I can’t answer specifics. My supervisor expects me to keep call times short and conversions high, but I’m stuck on the line, fumbling for answers, feeling my confidence slip.

Alex wants me present, laughing and relaxed, not distracted or exhausted. But every evening I consider for our date, I remember the stack of product manuals I promised myself I’d study, hoping to handle tomorrow’s calls better. I want to be the attentive girlfriend he deserves, but I also need to be the competent telemarketer my job demands. My heart aches as I stare at Alex’s message, torn between the warmth of his company and the pressure to prove myself at work.
